explanations.A: Rearranging the part squares to form full squares we would be able to count 6 full squares. Therefore the area of the shape is 6.
explanations.B: Not quite. We cannot count the squares that are NOT fully shaded. Can you combine partly shaded squares to form fully shaded squares? How many full squares would then be shaded?
explanations.C: There are 4 fully shaded squares but the area includes those squares that are partially shaded. Can you combine these squares to form fully shaded squares? How many full squares would then be shaded?
explanations.D: Not quite. Those 4 partially shaded squares can pair up to make more than one fully shaded square.

explanations.A: Area of parallelogram = base ✕ perpendicular height. In this diagram, the base is represented by b, and the perpendicular height is c because this is at right angles to b. Therefore, length a is not needed.
explanations.B: Not quite. Turning the shape 90⁰ might help you see which lengths we would use to find the area.
explanations.C: Be careful. Remember the area of a parallelogram = base x perpendicular height.
explanations.D: Not quite. Multiplying three lengths would calculate a volume not an area. Which length do we not need?

explanations.A: I think you've doubled the length. Remember that to find the area of a square, we multiply the side length by the side length.
explanations.B: I think you've calculated the perimeter. Remember that to find the area of a square, we multiply the side length by the side length.
explanations.C: Area of a square = side × side. Because each side of a square is the same, it can simply be the length of one side squared, so in this case 12 × 12 = 12² = 144 cm².
explanations.D: So close! I think you've divided by 2 to get your answer. We don't need to halve the answer with squares.
